body: SCHREIBMAN--Lucille, 87, of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn and Boca Raton, FL. Loving mother of Sam, Ilys, Sheryl, Neal, Joan and Claire. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services were held.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHREIBMAN, LUCILLE

body: James F. Clarity, a reporter who covered crime, politics, sports and wars in 40 years of newspapering, mostly for The New York Times, died Thursday at his home in Long Branch, N.J. He was 75. The cause was a heart attack, said his former wife, Elizabeth Sheehan. Bearded, rumpled and irascible, Mr. Clarity looked like a screenwriter's version of an
title: James F. Clarity, 75; Reported on Crime, Politics and War

body: A ''Living In'' article last Sunday, about Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, misidentified the ethnic group most closely identified with the neighborhood. It is Jewish, not Italian. In addition, a picture caption misstated the name of the street shown. It is Ocean Avenue, not Boulevard. And a map misstated the name of another street and misidentified one
title: CORRECTION; Real Estate

body: THE word ''beach'' in the name of a New York neighborhood is no proof of the presence of sand. Bath Beach, for instance, doesn't have any. Yet Manhattan Beach, on a peninsula in Brooklyn's southeastern corner, has not just one beach, but two. To start with, there is the 400-foot-wide crescent at Kingsborough Community College, whose 70-acre campus
title: LIVING IN | MANHATTAN BEACH, BROOKLYN; A Little Land With a Lot of Sand

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street, Lincoln Center. Through Oct. 10, Plaza Library and Steinberg Room Gallery, ''Cloud Gate in Photographs,'' an exhibition that features the photographs of Cloud Gate, the Taiwanese experimental dance company. title: Around Town

body: AROUND TOWN REVENGE OF THE BOOKEATERS Whether they always finished their own homework is debatable, but on Sunday evening a Who's Who of downtown comedy stars, writers and indie rockers will perform in a benefit show for 826NYC, the free tutoring center for children in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Among those scheduled to appear are Feist, the indie
title: Spare Times

body: IT was the pale green and pink striped bikini that did it. When Sandra Cornier, a mother of two from Brooklyn, looked at a recent photo of herself taken at Manhattan Beach, N.Y., she didn't like what she saw. She had been nursing her son for 11 months, and now she could barely fill out the bathing suit top. She made a decision: She would have
title: Who Is the Real Face Of Plastic Surgery?

body: The city's beaches are sorely in need of improvement, a survey by an independent watchdog group concluded in a report released yesterday, citing too much litter and too few lifeguards as being among the most common problems at the seven city-operated beaches. The group, New Yorkers for Parks, in its first beach survey, gave only one -- Midland
title: Beaches Get Poor Grades In Report By Monitor

body: On a November day in 1776, a 25-year-old woman named Margaret Corbin joined her husband, John, in defending Fort Washington, in Upper Manhattan, from an attack by the British. When John Corbin was killed, his wife took over at the cannon he had been firing and fought valiantly until she herself was shot. The British overtook the fort, but Margaret
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN BEACH; A Street Named Trouble

body: 'BIGLITTLETHINGS' (Tomorrow) One of those little things is big indeed: a dinosaur, to be wrestled by cavemen. That's just one of the illusions by Imago Theater, a duo that uses masks, costumes, props and choreography. At noon and 3 p.m., Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 760-0064, queenstheatre.org; $17; $15 for ages
title: SPARE TIMES: March 16 - March 22; For Children

author: Leonard Benardo and Jennifer Weiss are the authors of ''Brooklyn by Name: How the Neighborhoods, Streets, Parks, Bridges and More Got Their Names'' and the forthcoming ''Out of Power,'' a study of former presidents.
body: A FEW weeks ago, most Brooklyn residents would have pleaded ignorance about the person for whom Manhattan Beach's Corbin Place is named. But with the recent airing of the distasteful history of the man Corbin Place memorializes, local politicians have been leading a charge to rename it. A public hearing on possibly renaming the street is scheduled
title: Street Cred

body: KLOTZ--Brenda Schulman, died February 15th, 2007. Born in Brooklyn, NY, February 11th, 1938. Formally of Manhattan Beach and Teaneck, NJ. Beloved twin sister and sister-in-law of Evelyn and Charles Falick, of NYC.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KLOTZ, BRENDA SCHULMAN

body: SALVAGE men tell good stories. The other day Gil Shapiro, whose high-end salvage-turned-reproduction company, Urban Archaeology, is a case study of the architectural remnant business as it has evolved over the past four decades, described his first purchase, as a high school senior in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. Walking home from school one day, Mr.
title: Top of the Heap: A Business Built on Salvage

body: FRIES--Jerome E. (Jack), 103 died Tuesday, February 6th in Boca Raton, Florida. Previously a resident of Brooklyn and Manhattan Beach, NY for 93 years. Beloved husband of 70 years to Sophia (deceased), father to Stuart and Ellie, Joseph and Fredi Ann, Arthur and Cindy. Grandfather to Jolie, Stacey, Todd, Justin, and Pamela, Chuck and Lori, David
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FRIES, JEROME E. (JACK)

body: Zettie is like many other fifth-grade girls. Her mother tucks her in lovingly at night, and when she wakes each morning, she rushes to wash and get ready for school. But Zettie's bed is a narrow, plastic-covered seat; her alarm clock is often a police siren; and the sink where she brushes her teeth is in a park restroom. Zettie (Emily Agy, above)
title: SPARE TIMES: Feb. 2 - Feb. 8; 'A SHELTER IN OUR CAR'
